newsitem.title: USA: North American PC software Q2 sales rise 5.7 pct.
newsitem.headline: North American PC software Q2 sales rise 5.7 pct.

text.p: Sales of personal computer application software in North America for the second quarter of the year totalled $2.18 billion, 5.7 percent higher than the same period last year, according to the Software Publishers Association.

The association said Wednesday that Microsoft Corp's Windows applications led sales growth during the quarter. Sales of combined 16- and 32-bit Windows applications increased 14 percent to $1.68 billion, it said.
Windows 32-bit (Windows 95 and NT) software continued to increase its market share, reaching $475.3 million or 21.7 percent of total software sales, it said.
Windows 16-bit software (Windows 3.x, comprising Windows 3.1 and 3.11, collectively) reached $1.2 billion or 55.3 percent of total software sales during the same period, it added.
The association said DOS application sales totalled a mere $127.5 million in sales, a 51 percent decrease from the previous year.

Sales of Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh applications fell 21 percent to $296.8 million, while Macintosh home creativity and databases showed strong growth, up 76.9 percent and 80.4 percent respectively, it said.

The association is the main software industry trade association, representing publishers as well as start-up firms in the business applications market, as well as home office, recreation, consumer and education markets.
